Different? That’s putting it mildly. I coordinated with the assembly to release the full BCI archives.

Did all my usual work, but stayed off the editing tools. Logged stories, kept records offline, tried to give people power over their own history.
Word got out. My colleagues questioned every move. Then Directorate shut me out, revoked everything.
Badge gone. BCI score cratered. Suddenly I’m public enemy—no warning, just a system alert.

All I can hear now are these voices from the mural, echoing back all the things we were never supposed to know.
Honestly? Everything’s upside down. I grew up inside this system. My mother ran compliance checks so I knew exactly how stories get erased.

None of it prepared me for how it feels to actually break the chain. I gave the instructions to open the BCI channel. Worked with assembly leaders so people could see the records for themselves, not just the state’s version.
I sat near the mural, catalogued every testimony—open abuse, accidental mercy, the things the algorithms missed on purpose.
By midday I lost my badge. Staff who used to buy me coffee now cross the street.
My score dropped to 5. To the system, I’m a saboteur now. But this city needed to see itself honestly, even if it cost me everything.
People are still bringing evidence. Stories that’d never get a hearing anywhere official. It’s dangerous, but it might finally mean something.
All this time, I thought I was just doing journalism. Turns out I was rebuilding the record of who we are.
And now? I feel like everything I thought I knew about this city is unraveling right in front of me.

After the archives opened, the city woke up. Stories at the mural went viral.
People stopped hiding. BCI files turned out way dirtier than state news ever admitted.

I’m glad people finally see what compliance really meant.
Letting the archives out changed everything. Not just protests—actual truth came out. People found the proof of who the system erased and why.
The mural became ground zero. Citizens cross-checking secrets, naming the old abuses. I catalogued so much—unexpected kindness, real betrayals.
Directorate moves harder but can’t contain it. Streams get mirrored, there’s always another phone.
The bogus calm is completely gone. Assemblies running on raw testimony, demanding resignations, accountability.
Used to be silence or rumors. Now it’s public standoffs and viral evidence. Feeds are full of citizen investigators.
Council was forced to kill the BCI just to stop the bleeding. Trust in them is zero.
I spent my life thinking journalism meant framing the story. Turns out the real story shapes itself, if you let people speak.
Honestly, this is the first time I’ve felt like rebellion could actually stick. The system wasn’t as invincible as they preached.
